title: CD2030 Extractor User Guide
text:
Overview of the Countdown to 2030
The Countdown to 2030 for Women’s, Children’s and Adolescents’ Health (The Countdown) initiative is a global collaboration involving academics from national, regional, and international institutions, UN agencies, the World Bank, and civil society organizations. The initiative tracks progress in Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health and Nutrition (RMNCAH+N), fostering advocacy and accountability through rigorous data analysis.
Key objectives include:

Strengthening country-led data analysis and monitoring
Fostering innovation and evidence generation through multi-country collaboration
Enhancing global measurement and monitoring Improving policy and program communication

For more on Countdown to 2030 initiative, visit: The Countdown website

title: CD2030 Extractor User Guide
text:
About the cd2030.extractor R Package
The cd2030.extractor R Shiny app was developed to help you download Countdown data directly from DHIS2. t works with DHIS2 in all supported countries.
Key features:

Clean, simple interface for selecting and managing data
Exports data in the standard Countdown format for analysis and reporting

title: 1  Getting started
text:
1.1 Software requirements
The tool simplifies the process of downloading country DHIS2 data, transforming it into a standardized Countdown format. It supports the mapping of country-specific RMNCAH indicators, which enhances data standardization and portability.
To use this innovative digital health analytics tool, the following are required:

title: 1  Getting started
text:
Install the latest versions of R and RStudio
Install RTools (for Windows users, to support package compilation)
Install the cd2030.extractor R package latest version-noted by the superscript suffix in the name of the App

title: 1  Getting started
text:
1.2 Installing R and RStudio
To begin working in R, it is necessary to install both R and RStudio. R is the underlying programming language, while RStudio provides a user-friendly interface that simplifies the development and execution of R scripts. Both are freely available and widely supported across platforms.
Note: R and RStudio are not the same. R is the programming language, while RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) that makes working with R easier.
To ensure smooth installation and functionality, it is recommended to install R first, followed by RStudio. This order is important as RStudio relies on R to function properly.

1.2.1 Step 1: Download and Install R
R is distributed via The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). Select your operating system from the homepage: Windows, Mac, or Linux.
Windows

Navigate to Download R for Windows and select the “base” option.
Click the first link (e.g., “Download R x.x.x for Windows”) to download the installer.
Run the installer and follow the prompts. Administrator privileges may be required.
R will be installed in your system’s Program Files, with a shortcut added to the Start menu.

Mac

Click Download R for Mac on the CRAN homepage.
Download the latest release package and run the installer.
The default installation settings are typically sufficient. You may be prompted to enter your system password.

Note
R is not a graphical software application but a programming environment. It is best used in conjunction with RStudio, which provides a consistent and user-friendly interface across operating systems.


1.2.2 Step 2: Download and Install RStudio
RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) designed for R. It features a script editor, console, graphics viewer, and additional tools for package management, debugging, and file organization.
Download RStudio from Posit Website
Do I still need to download R? Even if you use RStudio, you’ll still need to download R to your computer. RStudio helps you use the version of R that lives on your computer, but it doesn’t come with a version of R on its own.
After installation, launch RStudio and begin interacting with R through its console and script windows.

title: 1  Getting started
text:
1.3 Installing the CD2030 Extractor package
After installing R and RStudio, you may proceed with installing the Countdown 2030 Extractor application, which is hosted on GitHub under the repository cd2030.extractor. The application is implemented as an R package and supports interactive dashboard generation via Shiny.

1.3.1 Installation via R Console

if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("aphrcwaro/dhis2")



1.3.2 Launching the Application

library(cd2030.extractor)
run_app()

The Shiny dashboard will launch automatically in your default web browser.











1.3.3 Alternative Installation via GitHub Desktop or Git or direct download
Advanced users with GitHub accounts may prefer to clone the repository directly. This method allows for:

Version control
Contribution to the codebase
Inspection of the package structure
Once cloned, open the .Rproj file in RStudio to set the working directory.
























To install and run:

devtools::load_all()
run_app()



1.3.4 RTools for Windows
To compile packages from source, especially development versions, RTools must be installed. Ensure the Rtools selected corresponds and is compatibile with your installed R version.:

R 4.2.0 → Rtools42
R 4.4.0 → Rtools44
R 4.5.0 → Rtools45

Rtools can be downloaded from CRAN

title: 2  App Features
text:
2.1 Overview of App Features
This section details the main components of the cd2030.extractor Shiny App interface: the Top Navigation Bar (Green Header), Sidebar (Data Controls), and Main Panel (Body Content). Understanding these elements will help you navigate and use the app more effectively.

title: 2  App Features
text:
2.2 Navigation Bar (Top Menu)
The Top Navigation Bar, located at the top of the app, provides key controls. The navigation tabs included Service Data, Population Data and Countdown Data. On the right side it contains the name of the logged in user and the country

2.2.1 Key Elements of the Top Navigation Bar

Service Data Tab: This is mean to download the data for.

images

Population Data Tab
Countdown Tab
Context Information

title: 2  App Features
text:
2.3 Sidebar
The Sidebar is located on the left side of the app and contains the main navigation elements.It provides navigation through the analysis workflow. The sections are arranged sequentially to guide you through the process.

2.3.1 Sidebar Navigation
images

Introduction: Provides a brief overview of the app’s purpose and functionality.
Load Data: Allows you to upload and manage your datasets (e.g. Health Facility Datasets, Master datasets, and cache file).
Data Quality: Provides tools for assessing the quality of your data, including checks for missing values and inconsistencies. Subsections include:

Reporting Rate
Outlier Detection
Consistency Check
Data Completeness
Calculate Ratios
Overall Score


images

Analysis Set-up: Allows you to configure the analysis by selecting the data sources (UN Estimates, WUENIC estimates, and survey data). It also allows you to map the sub-national survey and mapping data to the uploaded data.

images

National Analysis: Provides tools for analyzing national-level data, including coverage and equity analysis.
Sub-National Analysis: For all sub-national analyses
Mortality Analysis: For all mortality analyses
Service Utilization: ForCurative health services utilization for sick children analyses
Health System Performance: Health systems progress and performance analysis

title: 2  App Features
text:
2.4 Main Panel(Body Content)
The main panel is the central workspace where the analysis result, visualizations, and interactive elements are displayed.

2.4.1 Key Elements of the Main Panel

Page Title: Displays the current module or analysis step (e.g., “Reporting Rate”).

images

Action Buttons: Provides context-specific actions:

Download Report: Helps you to download two reports: Synthesis report and the Subnational one paper report
Generate Report: Downloads a report specific to the analysis section.
NB: This button is green in colour and only appears in the sections where the user can download the section reports.
Get Help: Provides context-specific help and documentation for the current page.
Download Plot / Download Data: Allows the user to download the displayed output and the data associated with the output, respectively.
